## 8.2. Countable and Uncountable Sets

Section 8.2 of *HTPI* shows that many set-theoretic operations, when applied to countable sets, produce results that are countable.  For example, the first part of Theorem 8.2.1 shows that a Cartesian product of countable sets is countable.  Our proof of this statement in Lean is based on `Theorem_8_1_2_1_set` and the denumerability of `Nat √ó Nat`.  We also use an exercise from Section 8.1.

```lean
theorem NxN_denum : denum (Nat √ó Nat) := Theorem_8_1_3_2 NxN_equinum_N

theorem Theorem_8_2_1_1 {U V : Type} {A : Set U} {B : Set V}
    (h1 : ctble A) (h2 : ctble B) : ctble (A √ó‚Çõ B) := by
  rewrite [ctble_iff_set_nat_equinum] at h1
  rewrite [ctble_iff_set_nat_equinum] at h2
  obtain (J : Set Nat) (h3 : J ‚àº A) from h1
  obtain (K : Set Nat) (h4 : K ‚àº B) from h2
  have h5 : J √ó‚Çõ K ‚àº A √ó‚Çõ B := Theorem_8_1_2_1_set h3 h4
  have h6 : ctble (Nat √ó Nat) := Or.inr NxN_denum
  have h7 : ctble (J √ó‚Çõ K) := ctble_set_of_ctble_type h6 (J √ó‚Çõ K)
  show ctble (A √ó‚Çõ B) from ctble_of_ctble_equinum h5 h7
  done
```

The second part of Theorem 8.2.1 shows that a union of two countable sets is countable, but, as we ask you to show in the exercises, it is superseded by Theorem 8.2.2, which says that a union of a countable family of countable sets is countable.  So we will skip ahead to Theorem 8.2.2.  Here's how we state the theorem in Lean:

```lean
theorem Theorem_8_2_2 {U : Type} {F : Set (Set U)}
    (h1 : ctble F) (h2 : ‚àÄ A ‚àà F, ctble A) : ctble (‚ãÉ‚ÇÄ F)
```

As in the proof in *HTPI*, we will use the characterization of countability from `Theorem_8_1_5_2`.  We first consider the case in which `F` is nonempty and also all elements of `F` are nonempty.  According to `Theorem_8_1_5_2`, the hypotheses `h1` and `h2` then imply that there is a function `j : Nat ‚Üí Set U` such that `F ‚äÜ range j`, and also for each `A ‚àà F` there is a function `gA : Nat ‚Üí U` with `A ‚äÜ range gA`.  We begin by proving an easier version of the theorem, where we assume that we have a function `g` from `Set U` to `Nat ‚Üí U` that supplies, for each `A ‚àà F`, the required function `gA`.  Imitating the proof in *HTPI*, we can use `j` and `g` to construct the function needed to prove that `‚ãÉ‚ÇÄ F` is countable.

```lean
lemma Lemma_8_2_2_1 {U : Type} {F : Set (Set U)} {g : Set U ‚Üí Nat ‚Üí U}
    (h1 : ctble F) (h2 : ¬¨empty F) (h3 : ‚àÄ A ‚àà F, A ‚äÜ range (g A)) :
    ctble (‚ãÉ‚ÇÄ F) := by
  rewrite [Theorem_8_1_5_2] at h1
  disj_syll h1 h2               --h1 : ‚àÉ (f : Nat ‚Üí Set U), F ‚äÜ range f
  rewrite [Theorem_8_1_5_2]
  apply Or.inr                  --Goal : ‚àÉ (f : Nat ‚Üí Set U), ‚ãÉ‚ÇÄF ‚äÜ range f
  obtain (j : Nat ‚Üí Set U) (h4 : F ‚äÜ range j) from h1
  obtain (p : Nat ‚Üí Nat √ó Nat) (h5 : one_to_one p ‚àß onto p) from NxN_denum
  set f : Nat ‚Üí U := fun (n : Nat) => g (j (p n).1) (p n).2
  apply Exists.intro f
  fix x : U
  assume h6 : x ‚àà ‚ãÉ‚ÇÄ F
  obtain (A : Set U) (h7 : A ‚àà F ‚àß x ‚àà A) from h6
  obtain (n1 : Nat) (h8 : j n1 = A) from h4 h7.left
  obtain (n2 : Nat) (h9 : g A n2 = x) from h3 A h7.left h7.right
  obtain (n : Nat) (h10 : p n = (n1, n2)) from h5.right (n1, n2)
  apply Exists.intro n
  show f n = x from
    calc f n
      _ = g (j (p n).1) (p n).2 := by rfl
      _ = g (j n1) n2 := by rw [h10]
      _ = g A n2 := by rw [h8]
      _ = x := by rw [h9]
  done
```

How can we use `Lemma_8_2_2_1` to prove `Theorem_8_2_2` (still assuming that `F` and every element of `F` are nonempty)?  We must use the hypothesis `h2 : ‚àÄ A ‚àà F, ctble A` in `Theorem_8_2_2` to produce the function `g` required in `Lemma_8_2_2_1`.  As we have already observed, `Theorem_8_1_5_2` guarantees that for each `A ‚àà F`, an appropriate function `gA : Nat ‚Üí U` exists.  We need a function `g` that will *choose* such a function `gA` for each `A`.  A function with this property is often called a *choice function*.  And now we come to a delicate point that was skipped over in *HTPI*: to prove the existence of a choice function, we must use a statement called the *axiom of choice*.^[The axiom of choice was first stated by Ernst Zermelo in 1904.  You can learn more about it in Gregory H. Moore, *Zermelo's Axiom of Choice: Its Origins, Development, and Influence*, Dover Publications, 2013.  See also <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Axiom_of_choice>.]

The distinction between the existence of an appropriate function `gA` for each `A` and the existence of a function that chooses such a function for each `A` is a subtle one.  Perhaps for this reason, many people find the axiom of choice to be intuitively obvious.  *HTPI* took advantage of this intuition to skip over this step in the proof without comment.  But of course Lean won't let us skip anything!

To implement the axiom of choice, Lean uses a function called `Classical.choose`.  Given a proof `h` of a statement of the form `‚àÉ (x : U), P x`, the expression `Classical.choose h` produces ("chooses") some `u : U` such that `P u` is true.  There is also a theorem `Classical.choose_spec` that guarantees that the `Classical.choose` function meets its specification---that is, `P (Classical.choose h)` is true.  Using these, we can prove a lemma that will bridge the gap between `Lemma_8_2_2_1` and `Theorem_8_2_2`.

```lean
lemma Lemma_8_2_2_2 {U : Type} {F : Set (Set U)} (h1 : ‚àÄ A ‚àà F, ctble A)
    (h2 : ¬¨empty F) (h3 : ‚àÄ A ‚àà F, ¬¨empty A):
    ‚àÉ (g : Set U ‚Üí Nat ‚Üí U), ‚àÄ A ‚àà F, A ‚äÜ range (g A) := by
  have h4 : ‚àÄ (A : Set U), ‚àÉ (gA : Nat ‚Üí U),
      A ‚àà F ‚Üí A ‚äÜ range gA := by
    fix A : Set U
    by_cases h4 : A ‚àà F
    ¬∑ -- Case 1. h4 : A ‚àà F
      have h5 : ctble A := h1 A h4
      rewrite [Theorem_8_1_5_2] at h5
      disj_syll h5 (h3 A h4)    --h5 : ‚àÉ (f : Nat ‚Üí U), A ‚äÜ range f
      obtain (gA : Nat ‚Üí U) (h6 : A ‚äÜ range gA) from h5
      apply Exists.intro gA
      assume h7 : A ‚àà F
      show A ‚äÜ range gA from h6
      done
    ¬∑ -- Case 2. h4 : A ‚àâ F
      rewrite [not_empty_iff_exists_elt] at h2
      obtain (A0 : Set U) (h5 : A0 ‚àà F) from h2
      have h6 : ¬¨empty A0 := h3 A0 h5
      rewrite [not_empty_iff_exists_elt] at h6
      obtain (x0 : U) (h7 : x0 ‚àà A0) from h6
      set gA : Nat ‚Üí U := constant_func Nat x0
      apply Exists.intro gA
      contrapos
      assume h8 : A ‚äà range gA
      show A ‚àâ F from h4
      done
    done
  set g : Set U ‚Üí Nat ‚Üí U := fun (A : Set U) => Classical.choose (h4 A)
  apply Exists.intro g
  fix A : Set U
  show A ‚àà F ‚Üí A ‚äÜ range (g A) from Classical.choose_spec (h4 A)
  done
```

Notice that the domain of the function `g` in `Lemma_8_2_2_2` is `Set U`, not `F`.  Thus, we must produce a function `gA` for every `A : Set U`, but it is only when `A ‚àà F` that we care what `gA` is.  Thus, the proof above just picks a default value (`constant_func Nat x0`) when `A ‚àâ F`.

We can now prove the theorem, still under the assumption that all elements of `F` are nonempty.  If `F` is empty, then we can show that `‚ãÉ‚ÇÄ F` is empty, so it has zero elements, which implies that it is finite and therefore countable.  If `F` is not empty, then we can combine `Lemma_8_2_2_1` and `Lemma_8_2_2_2` to prove the theorem.

```lean
lemma Lemma_8_2_2_3 {U : Type} {F : Set (Set U)}
    (h1 : ctble F) (h2 : ‚àÄ A ‚àà F, ctble A) (h3 : ‚àÄ A ‚àà F, ¬¨empty A) :
    ctble (‚ãÉ‚ÇÄ F) := by
  by_cases h4 : empty F
  ¬∑ -- Case 1. h4 : empty F
    have h5 : empty (‚ãÉ‚ÇÄ F) := by
      contradict h4 with h5
      rewrite [not_empty_iff_exists_elt] at h5
      obtain (x : U) (h6 : x ‚àà ‚ãÉ‚ÇÄ F) from h5
      obtain (A : Set U) (h7 : A ‚àà F ‚àß x ‚àà A) from h6
      show ‚àÉ (x : Set U), x ‚àà F from Exists.intro A h7.left
      done
    rewrite [‚Üêzero_elts_iff_empty] at h5    --h5 : numElts (‚ãÉ‚ÇÄ F) 0
    define
    apply Or.inl
    rewrite [finite_def]
    show ‚àÉ (n : Nat), numElts (‚ãÉ‚ÇÄ F) n from Exists.intro 0 h5
    done
  ¬∑ -- Case 2. h4 : ¬¨empty F
    obtain (g : Set U ‚Üí Nat ‚Üí U) (h5 : ‚àÄ A ‚àà F, A ‚äÜ range (g A)) from
      Lemma_8_2_2_2 h2 h4 h3
    show ctble (‚ãÉ‚ÇÄ F) from Lemma_8_2_2_1 h1 h4 h5
    done
```

Finally, we deal with the possibility that `F` contains the empty set.  As in *HTPI*, we show that we can simply remove the empty set from `F` and then apply our earlier reasoning.

```lean
lemma remove_empty_subset {U : Type} (F : Set (Set U)) :
    {A : Set U | A ‚àà F ‚àß ¬¨empty A} ‚äÜ F := by
  fix X : Set U
  assume h1 : X ‚àà {A : Set U | A ‚àà F ‚àß ¬¨empty A}
  define at h1
  show X ‚àà F from h1.left
  done

lemma remove_empty_union_eq {U : Type} (F : Set (Set U)) :
    ‚ãÉ‚ÇÄ {A : Set U | A ‚àà F ‚àß ¬¨empty A} = ‚ãÉ‚ÇÄ F := sorry

theorem Theorem_8_2_2 {U : Type} {F : Set (Set U)}
    (h1 : ctble F) (h2 : ‚àÄ A ‚àà F, ctble A) : ctble (‚ãÉ‚ÇÄ F) := by
  set G : Set (Set U) := {A : Set U | A ‚àà F ‚àß ¬¨empty A}
  have h3 : G ‚äÜ F := remove_empty_subset F
  have h4 : ‚ãÉ‚ÇÄ G = ‚ãÉ‚ÇÄ F := remove_empty_union_eq F
  rewrite [‚Üêh4]
  have h5 : ctble G := Exercise_8_1_17 h3 h1
  have h6 : ‚àÄ A ‚àà G, ctble A := by
    fix A : Set U
    assume h6 : A ‚àà G
    show ctble A from h2 A (h3 h6)
    done
  have h7 : ‚àÄ A ‚àà G, ¬¨empty A := by
    fix A : Set U
    assume h7 : A ‚àà G
    define at h7
    show ¬¨empty A from h7.right
    done
  show ctble (‚ãÉ‚ÇÄ G) from Lemma_8_2_2_3 h5 h6 h7
  done
```

By the way, we can now explain a mystery from Section 5.1.  The reason we skipped the proof of the right-to-left direction of `func_from_graph` is that the proof uses `Classical.choose` and `Classical.choose_spec`.  Now that you know about this function and theorem, we can show you the proof.

```lean
theorem func_from_graph_rtl {A B : Type} (F : Set (A √ó B)) :
    is_func_graph F ‚Üí (‚àÉ (f : A ‚Üí B), graph f = F) := by
  assume h1 : is_func_graph F
  define at h1    --h1 : ‚àÄ (x : A), ‚àÉ! (y : B), (x, y) ‚àà F
  have h2 : ‚àÄ (x : A), ‚àÉ (y : B), (x, y) ‚àà F := by
    fix x : A
    obtain (y : B) (h3 : (x, y) ‚àà F)
      (h4 : ‚àÄ (y1 y2 : B), (x, y1) ‚àà F ‚Üí (x, y2) ‚àà F ‚Üí y1 = y2) from h1 x
    show ‚àÉ (y : B), (x, y) ‚àà F from Exists.intro y h3
    done
  set f : A ‚Üí B := fun (x : A) => Classical.choose (h2 x)
  apply Exists.intro f
  apply Set.ext
  fix (x, y) : A √ó B
  have h3 : (x, f x) ‚àà F := Classical.choose_spec (h2 x)
  apply Iff.intro
  ¬∑ -- (‚Üí)
    assume h4 : (x, y) ‚àà graph f
    define at h4        --h4 : f x = y
    rewrite [h4] at h3
    show (x, y) ‚àà F from h3
    done
  ¬∑ -- (‚Üê)
    assume h4 : (x, y) ‚àà F
    define              --Goal : f x = y
    obtain (z : B) (h5 : (x, z) ‚àà F)
      (h6 : ‚àÄ (y1 y2 : B), (x, y1) ‚àà F ‚Üí (x, y2) ‚àà F ‚Üí y1 = y2) from h1 x
    show f x = y from h6 (f x) y h3 h4
    done
  done
```

There is one more theorem in Section 8.2 of *HTPI* showing that a set-theoretic operation, when applied to a countable set, gives a countable result.  Theorem 8.2.4 says that if a set $A$ is countable, then the set of all finite sequences of elements of $A$ is also countable.  In *HTPI*, finite sequences are represented by functions, but in Lean it is easier to use lists.  Thus, if `A` has type `Set U`, then we define a *finite sequence of elements of `A`* to be a list `l : List U` with the property that every entry of `l` is an element of `A`.  Letting `seq A` denote the set of all finite sequences of elements of `A`, our version of Theorem 8.2.4 will say that if `A` is countable, then so is `seq A`.

```lean
def seq {U : Type} (A : Set U) : Set (List U) :=
  {l : List U | ‚àÄ x ‚àà l, x ‚àà A}

lemma seq_def {U : Type} (A : Set U) (l : List U) :
    l ‚àà seq A ‚Üî ‚àÄ x ‚àà l, x ‚àà A := by rfl

theorem Theorem_8_2_4 {U : Type} {A : Set U}
    (h1 : ctble A) : ctble (seq A)
```

Our proof of `Theorem_8_2_4` will use exactly the same strategy as the proof in *HTPI*.  We begin by showing that, for every natural number `n`, the set of sequences of elements of `A` of length `n` is countable.  The proof is by mathematical induction.  The base case is easy, because the only sequence of length `0` is the `nil` list.

```lean
def seq_by_length {U : Type} (A : Set U) (n : Nat) : Set (List U) :=
  {l : List U | l ‚àà seq A ‚àß l.length = n}

lemma sbl_base {U : Type} (A : Set U) : seq_by_length A 0 = {[]} := by
  apply Set.ext
  fix l : List U
  apply Iff.intro
  ¬∑ -- (‚Üí)
    assume h1 : l ‚àà seq_by_length A 0
    define at h1   --h1 : l ‚àà seq A ‚àß l.length = 0
    rewrite [List.length_eq_zero_iff] at h1
    define
    show l = [] from h1.right
    done
  ¬∑ -- (‚Üê)
    assume h1 : l ‚àà {[]}
    define at h1     --h1 : l = []
    define           --Goal : l ‚àà seq A ‚àß l.length = 0
    apply And.intro _ (List.length_eq_zero_iff.rtl h1)
    define           --Goal : ‚àÄ x ‚àà l, x ‚àà A
    fix x : U
    contrapos
    assume h2 : x ‚àâ A
    rewrite [h1]
    show x ‚àâ [] from List.not_mem_nil
    done
  done
```

For the induction step, the key idea is that `A √ó‚Çõ (seq_by_length A n) ‚àº seq_by_length A (n + 1)`.  To prove this, we define a function `seq_cons U` that matches up `A √ó‚Çõ (seq_by_length A n)` with `seq_by_length A (n + 1)`.

```lean
def seq_cons (U : Type) (p : U √ó (List U)) : List U := p.1 :: p.2

lemma seq_cons_def {U : Type} (x : U) (l : List U) :
    seq_cons U (x, l) = x :: l := by rfl

lemma seq_cons_one_one (U : Type) : one_to_one (seq_cons U) := by
  fix (a1, l1) : U √ó List U; fix (a2, l2) : U √ó List U
  assume h1 : seq_cons U (a1, l1) = seq_cons U (a2, l2)
  rewrite [seq_cons_def, seq_cons_def] at h1  --h1 : a1 :: l1 = a2 :: l2
  rewrite [List.cons_eq_cons] at h1           --h1 : a1 = a2 ‚àß l1 = l2
  rewrite [h1.left, h1.right]
  rfl
  done

lemma seq_cons_image {U : Type} (A : Set U) (n : Nat) :
    image (seq_cons U) (A √ó‚Çõ (seq_by_length A n)) =
      seq_by_length A (n + 1) := sorry

lemma Lemma_8_2_4_1 {U : Type} (A : Set U) (n : Nat) :
    A √ó‚Çõ (seq_by_length A n) ‚àº seq_by_length A (n + 1) := by
  rewrite [‚Üêseq_cons_image A n]
  show A √ó‚Çõ seq_by_length A n ‚àº
    image (seq_cons U) (A √ó‚Çõ seq_by_length A n) from equinum_image
    (one_one_on_of_one_one (seq_cons_one_one U) (A √ó‚Çõ (seq_by_length A n)))
  done
```

With this preparation, we can now use `singleton_one_elt` to justify the base case of our induction proof and `Theorem_8_2_1_1` for the induction step.

```lean
lemma Lemma_8_2_4_2 {U : Type} {A : Set U} (h1 : ctble A) :
    ‚àÄ (n : Nat), ctble (seq_by_length A n) := by
  by_induc
  ¬∑ -- Base Case
    rewrite [sbl_base]   --Goal : ctble {[]}
    define
    apply Or.inl         --Goal : finite {[]}
    rewrite [finite_def]
    apply Exists.intro 1 --Goal : numElts {[]} 1
    show numElts {[]} 1 from singleton_one_elt []
    done
  ¬∑ -- Induction Step
    fix n : Nat
    assume ih : ctble (seq_by_length A n)
    have h2 : A √ó‚Çõ (seq_by_length A n) ‚àº seq_by_length A (n + 1) :=
      Lemma_8_2_4_1 A n
    have h3 : ctble (A √ó‚Çõ (seq_by_length A n)) := Theorem_8_2_1_1 h1 ih
    show ctble (seq_by_length A (n + 1)) from ctble_of_ctble_equinum h2 h3
    done
  done
```

Our next step is to show that the union of all of the sets `seq_by_length A n`, for `n : Nat`, is `seq A`.

```lean
def sbl_set {U : Type} (A : Set U) : Set (Set (List U)) :=
  {S : Set (List U) | ‚àÉ (n : Nat), seq_by_length A n = S}

lemma Lemma_8_2_4_3 {U : Type} (A : Set U) : ‚ãÉ‚ÇÄ (sbl_set A) = seq A := by
  apply Set.ext
  fix l : List U
  apply Iff.intro
  ¬∑ -- (‚Üí)
    assume h1 : l ‚àà ‚ãÉ‚ÇÄ (sbl_set A)
    define at h1
    obtain (S : Set (List U)) (h2 :  S ‚àà sbl_set A ‚àß l ‚àà S) from h1
    have h3 : S ‚àà sbl_set A := h2.left
    define at h3
    obtain (n : Nat) (h4 : seq_by_length A n = S) from h3
    have h5 : l ‚àà S := h2.right
    rewrite [‚Üêh4] at h5
    define at h5
    show l ‚àà seq A from h5.left
    done
  ¬∑ -- (‚Üê)
    assume h1 : l ‚àà seq A
    define
    set n : Nat := l.length
    apply Exists.intro (seq_by_length A n)
    apply And.intro
    ¬∑ -- Proof of seq_by_length A n ‚àà sbl_set A
      define
      apply Exists.intro n
      rfl
      done
    ¬∑ -- Proof of l ‚àà seq_by_length A n
      define
      apply And.intro h1
      rfl
      done
    done
  done
```

Of course, `sbl_set A` is countable.  The easiest way to prove this is to note that `seq_by_length A` is a function from `Nat` to `Set (List U)` whose range contains all of the sets in `sbl_set A`.

```lean
lemma Lemma_8_2_4_4 {U : Type} (A : Set U) : ctble (sbl_set A) := by
  rewrite [Theorem_8_1_5_2]
  apply Or.inr   --Goal : ‚àÉ (f : Nat ‚Üí Set (List U)), sbl_set A ‚äÜ range f
  apply Exists.intro (seq_by_length A)
  fix S : Set (List U)
  assume h1 : S ‚àà sbl_set A
  define at h1; define
  show ‚àÉ (x : Nat), seq_by_length A x = S from h1
  done
```

We now have everything we need to prove `Theorem_8_2_4` as an application of `Theorem_8_2_2`.

```lean
theorem Theorem_8_2_4 {U : Type} {A : Set U}
    (h1 : ctble A) : ctble (seq A) := by
  set F : Set (Set (List U)) := sbl_set A
  have h2 : ctble F := Lemma_8_2_4_4 A
  have h3 : ‚àÄ S ‚àà F, ctble S := by
    fix S : Set (List U)
    assume h3 : S ‚àà F
    define at h3
    obtain (n : Nat) (h4 : seq_by_length A n = S) from h3
    rewrite [‚Üêh4]
    show ctble (seq_by_length A n) from Lemma_8_2_4_2 h1 n
    done
  rewrite [‚ÜêLemma_8_2_4_3 A]
  show ctble (‚ãÉ‚ÇÄ sbl_set A) from Theorem_8_2_2 h2 h3
  done
```

There is a set-theoretic operation that can produce an uncountable set from a countable set: the power set operation.  *HTPI* demonstrates this by proving Cantor's theorem (Theorem 8.2.5), which says that $\mathscr{P}(\mathbb{Z}^+)$ is uncountable.  The strategy for this proof is tricky; it involves defining a set $D$ using a method called *diagonalization*.  For an explanation of the motivation behind this strategy, see *HTPI*.

Here we will prove in Lean that the collection of all sets of natural numbers is uncountable.  There is no need to use the power set operation for this, because we have a type, namely `Set Nat`, that contains all sets of natural numbers.  So our Lean version of Cantor's theorem says that `Set Nat` is uncountable.

```lean
theorem Cantor's_theorem : ¬¨ctble (Set Nat) := by
  by_contra h1
  rewrite [ctble_iff_set_nat_equinum] at h1
  obtain (J : Set Nat) (h2 : J ‚àº Set Nat) from h1
  obtain (F : J ‚Üí Set Nat) (h3 : one_to_one F ‚àß onto F) from h2
  set f : Nat ‚Üí Set Nat := func_extend F ‚àÖ
  set D : Set Nat := {n : Nat | n ‚àâ f n}
  obtain (nJ : J) (h4 : F nJ = D) from h3.right D
  set n : Nat := nJ.val
  have h5 : n ‚àà D ‚Üî n ‚àâ f n := by rfl
  have h6 : f n = F nJ := fe_elt F ‚àÖ nJ
  rewrite [h6, h4] at h5      --h5 : n ‚àà D ‚Üî n ‚àâ D
  by_cases h7 : n ‚àà D
  ¬∑ -- Case 1. h7 : n ‚àà D
    contradict h7
    show n ‚àâ D from h5.ltr h7
    done
  ¬∑ -- Case 2. h7 : n ‚àâ D
    contradict h7
    show n ‚àà D from h5.rtl h7
    done
  done
```

As a consequence of Theorem 8.2.5, *HTPI* shows that $\mathbb{R}$ is uncountable.  The proof is not hard, but it requires facts about the decimal expansions of real numbers.  Developing those facts in Lean would take us too far afield, so we will skip the proof.

## 8.3. The Cantor--Schr√∂der--Bernstein Theorem

The final section of *HTPI* proves the Cantor--Schr√∂der--Bernstein theorem.  The theorem says that if we have two sets such that there is a one-to-one function from each set to the other, then the two sets are equinumerous.  We will prove it in Lean for types, but of course we can apply it to sets as well by coercing the sets to subtypes.

```lean
theorem Cantor_Schroeder_Bernstein_theorem
    {U V : Type} {f : U ‚Üí V} {g : V ‚Üí U}
    (h1 : one_to_one f) (h2 : one_to_one g) : U ‚àº V
```

To prove the theorem, we must produce a one-to-one, onto function `h` from `U` to `V`.  Imitating the proof in *HTPI*, we will do this by defining a set `X : Set U` and then using `f` to determine the values of `h` on elements of the domain that belong to `X` and the inverse of `g` for those that don't.  That is, the graph of `h` will be the set `csb_func_graph f g X` defined as follows:

```lean
def csb_func_graph {U V : Type}
  (f : U ‚Üí V) (g : V ‚Üí U) (X : Set U) : Set (U √ó V) :=
  {(x, y) : U √ó V | (x ‚àà X ‚àß f x = y) ‚à® (x ‚àâ X ‚àß g y = x)}
```

Is `csb_func_graph f g X` the graph of a function?  It is not hard to show that it is, as long as `‚àÄ (x : U), x ‚àâ X ‚Üí x ‚àà range g`.  We first state lemmas spelling out the two cases in the definition of `csb_func_graph f g X`, leaving the proof of the second as an exercise for you.

```lean
lemma csb_func_graph_X {U V : Type} {X : Set U} {x : U}
    (f : U ‚Üí V) (g : V ‚Üí U) (h : x ‚àà X) (y : V) :
    (x, y) ‚àà csb_func_graph f g X ‚Üî f x = y := by
  apply Iff.intro
  ¬∑ -- (‚Üí)
    assume h1 : (x, y) ‚àà csb_func_graph f g X
    define at h1
    have h2 : ¬¨(x ‚àâ X ‚àß g y = x) := by
      demorgan
      show x ‚àà X ‚à® g y ‚â† x from Or.inl h
      done
    disj_syll h1 h2        --h1 : x ‚àà X ‚àß f x = y
    show f x = y from h1.right
    done
  ¬∑ -- (‚Üê)
    assume h1 : f x = y
    define
    apply Or.inl
    show x ‚àà X ‚àß f x = y from And.intro h h1
    done
  done

lemma csb_func_graph_not_X {U V : Type} {X : Set U} {x : U}
    (f : U ‚Üí V) (g : V ‚Üí U) (h : x ‚àâ X) (y : V) :
    (x, y) ‚àà csb_func_graph f g X ‚Üî g y = x := sorry

lemma csb_func_graph_is_func_graph {U V : Type} {g : V ‚Üí U} {X : Set U}
    (f : U ‚Üí V) (h1 : ‚àÄ (x : U), x ‚àâ X ‚Üí x ‚àà range g) (h2 : one_to_one g) :
    is_func_graph (csb_func_graph f g X) := by
  define
  fix x : U
  by_cases h3 : x ‚àà X
  ¬∑ -- Case 1. h3 : x ‚àà X
    exists_unique
    ¬∑ -- Existence
      apply Exists.intro (f x)
      rewrite [csb_func_graph_X f g h3]
      rfl
      done
    ¬∑ -- Uniqueness
      fix y1 : V; fix y2 : V
      assume h4 : (x, y1) ‚àà csb_func_graph f g X
      assume h5 : (x, y2) ‚àà csb_func_graph f g X
      rewrite [csb_func_graph_X f g h3] at h4  --h4 : f x = y1
      rewrite [csb_func_graph_X f g h3] at h5  --h5 : f x = y2
      rewrite [‚Üêh4, ‚Üêh5]
      rfl
      done
    done
  ¬∑ -- Case 2. h3 : x ‚àâ X
    exists_unique
    ¬∑ -- Existence
      obtain (y : V) (h4 : g y = x) from h1 x h3
      apply Exists.intro y
      rewrite [csb_func_graph_not_X f g h3]
      show g y = x from h4
      done
    ¬∑ -- Uniqueness
      fix y1 : V; fix y2 : V
      assume h4 : (x, y1) ‚àà csb_func_graph f g X
      assume h5 : (x, y2) ‚àà csb_func_graph f g X
      rewrite [csb_func_graph_not_X f g h3] at h4 --h4 : g y1 = x
      rewrite [csb_func_graph_not_X f g h3] at h5 --h5 : g y2 = x
      rewrite [‚Üêh5] at h4
      show y1 = y2 from h2 y1 y2 h4
      done
    done
  done
```

Our plan is to define `h` to be the function whose graph is `csb_func_graph f g X`.  With this definition, the value of `h x` for any `x : U` can be determined by a simple rule: if `x ‚àà X`, then `h x = f x`, and if `x ‚àâ X`, then `h x` has the property that `g (h x) = x`:

```lean
lemma csb_func_X
    {U V : Type} {f h : U ‚Üí V} {g : V ‚Üí U} {X : Set U} {x : U}
    (h1 : graph h = csb_func_graph f g X) (h2 : x ‚àà X) : h x = f x := by
  rewrite [‚Üêgraph_def, h1, csb_func_graph_X f g h2]
  rfl
  done

lemma csb_func_not_X
    {U V : Type} {f h : U ‚Üí V} {g : V ‚Üí U} {X : Set U} {x : U}
    (h1 : graph h = csb_func_graph f g X) (h2 : x ‚àâ X) : g (h x) = x := by
  have h3 : (x, h x) ‚àà graph h := by rfl
  rewrite [h1, csb_func_graph_not_X f g h2] at h3
  show g (h x) = x from h3
  done
```

We still have to say how `X` will be defined.  Let `A0 = {x : U | x ‚àâ range g}`.  To make sure that the condition `‚àÄ (x : U), x ‚àâ X ‚Üí x ‚àà range g` is satisfied, we will need to have `A0 ‚äÜ X`.  As explained in *HTPI*, we can now get a suitable set `X` by repeatedly taking the image of `A0` under `g ‚àò f`.  Fortunately, we defined functions in Section 6.5 that do what we need: `rep_image (g ‚àò f) n A0` is the result of taking the image of `A0` under `g ‚àò f` `n` times.  That is, `rep_image (g ‚àò f) 0 A0 = A0`, `rep_image (g ‚àò f) 1 A0 = image (g ‚àò f) A0`, `rep_image (g ‚àò f) 2 A0 = image (g ‚àò f) (image (g ‚àò f) A0)`, and so on.  We will define `X` to be the union of all of the sets `rep_image (g ‚àò f) n A0`, which is given by the function `cumul_image (g ‚àò f) A0`.

To prove that `h` is one-to-one, we will need to know that it cannot happen that `h x1 = h x2`, `x1 ‚àà X`, and `x2 ‚àâ X`.  After proving this last lemma, we are ready to prove the Cantor--Schr√∂der--Bernstein theorem.

```lean
lemma csb_X_of_X
    {U V : Type} {f h : U ‚Üí V} {g : V ‚Üí U} {A0 : Set U} {x1 x2 : U}
    (h1 : graph h = csb_func_graph f g (cumul_image (g ‚àò f) A0))
    (h2 : h x1 = h x2) (h3 : x1 ‚àà cumul_image (g ‚àò f) A0) :
    x2 ‚àà cumul_image (g ‚àò f) A0 := by
  by_contra h4                      --h4 : x2 ‚àâ cumul_image (g ‚àò f) A0
  rewrite [csb_func_X h1 h3] at h2  --h2 : f x1 = h x2
  have h5 : (g ‚àò f) x1 = x2 :=
    calc (g ‚àò f) x1
      _ = g (f x1) := by rfl
      _ = g (h x2) := by rw [h2]
      _ = x2 := csb_func_not_X h1 h4
  obtain (n : Nat) (h6 : x1 ‚àà rep_image (g ‚àò f) n A0) from h3
  contradict h4               --Goal : x2 ‚àà cumul_image (g ‚àò f) A0
  apply Exists.intro (n + 1)  --Goal : x2 ‚àà rep_image (g ‚àò f) (n + 1) A0
  rewrite [rep_image_step]
  apply Exists.intro x1
  show x1 ‚àà rep_image (g ‚àò f) n A0 ‚àß (g ‚àò f) x1 = x2 from
    And.intro h6 h5
  done

theorem Cantor_Schroeder_Bernstein_theorem
    {U V : Type} {f : U ‚Üí V} {g : V ‚Üí U}
    (h1 : one_to_one f) (h2 : one_to_one g) : U ‚àº V := by
  set A0 : Set U := {x : U | x ‚àâ range g}
  set X : Set U := cumul_image (g ‚àò f) A0
  set H : Set (U √ó V) := csb_func_graph f g X
  have h3 : ‚àÄ (x : U), x ‚àâ X ‚Üí x ‚àà range g := by
    fix x : U
    contrapos
    assume h3 : x ‚àâ range g
    define
    apply Exists.intro 0
    rewrite [rep_image_base]
    show x ‚àà A0 from h3
    done
  have h4 : is_func_graph H := csb_func_graph_is_func_graph f h3 h2
  rewrite [‚Üêfunc_from_graph] at h4
  obtain (h : U ‚Üí V) (h5 : graph h = H) from h4
  apply Exists.intro h
  apply And.intro
  ¬∑ -- proof that h is one-to-one
    fix x1 : U; fix x2 : U
    assume h6 : h x1 = h x2
    by_cases h7 : x1 ‚àà X
    ¬∑ -- Case 1. h7 : x1 ‚àà X
      have h8 : x2 ‚àà X := csb_X_of_X h5 h6 h7
      rewrite [csb_func_X h5 h7, csb_func_X h5 h8] at h6 --h6 : f x1 = f x2
      show x1 = x2 from h1 x1 x2 h6
      done
    ¬∑ -- Case 2. h7 : x1 ‚àâ X
      have h8 : x2 ‚àâ X := by
        contradict h7 with h8
        show x1 ‚àà X from csb_X_of_X h5 h6.symm h8
        done
      show x1 = x2 from
        calc x1
          _ = g (h x1) := (csb_func_not_X h5 h7).symm
          _ = g (h x2) := by rw [h6]
          _ = x2 := csb_func_not_X h5 h8
      done
    done
  ¬∑ -- proof that h is onto
    fix y : V
    by_cases h6 : g y ‚àà X
    ¬∑ -- Case 1. h6 : g y ‚àà X
      define at h6
      obtain (n : Nat) (h7 : g y ‚àà rep_image (g ‚àò f) n A0) from h6
      have h8 : n ‚â† 0 := by
        by_contra h8
        rewrite [h8, rep_image_base] at h7 --h7 : g y ‚àà A0
        define at h7                       --h7 : ¬¨‚àÉ (x : V), g x = g y
        contradict h7
        apply Exists.intro y
        rfl
        done
      obtain (k : Nat) (h9 : n = k + 1) from
        exists_eq_add_one_of_ne_zero h8
      rewrite [h9, rep_image_step] at h7
      obtain (x : U)
        (h10 : x ‚àà rep_image (g ‚àò f) k A0 ‚àß (g ‚àò f) x = g y) from h7
      have h11 : g (f x) = g y := h10.right
      have h12 : f x = y := h2 (f x) y h11
      have h13 : x ‚àà X := Exists.intro k h10.left
      apply Exists.intro x
      rewrite [csb_func_X h5 h13]
      show f x = y from h12
      done
    ¬∑ -- Case 2. h6 : g y ‚àâ X
      apply Exists.intro (g y)
      have h7 : g (h (g y)) = g y := csb_func_not_X h5 h6
      show h (g y) = y from h2 (h (g y)) y h7
      done
    done
  done
```

The next six exercises lead up to a proof that the set of all equivalence relations on the natural numbers is equinumerous with the type `Set Nat`.  These exercises use the following definitions:

```lean
def EqRel (U : Type) : Set (BinRel U) :=
  {R : BinRel U | equiv_rel R}

def Part (U : Type) : Set (Set (Set U)) :=
  {P : Set (Set U) | partition P}

def EqRelExt (U : Type) : Set (Set (U √ó U)) :=
  {E : Set (U √ó U) | ‚àÉ (R : BinRel U), equiv_rel R ‚àß extension R = E}

def shift_and_zero (X : Set Nat) : Set Nat :=
  {x + 2 | x ‚àà X} ‚à™ {0}

def shift_and_zero_comp (X : Set Nat) : Set Nat :=
  {n : Nat | n ‚àâ shift_and_zero X}

def saz_pair (X : Set Nat) : Set (Set Nat) :=
  {shift_and_zero X, shift_and_zero_comp X}
```
